column1: #Text=Polycrystalline LaPt3P [1] samples (sample-A) were synthesized by a solid state reaction method.
#Text=Powders of elemental platinum, red phosphorus, and alkaline earth (lanthanum) were mixed in an argon-filled glove box, and sealed in a quartz tube filled with argon gas.
#Text=The tube was initially heated to 400 ◦C and held at this temperature for 12 h in order to avoid rapid volatilization of phosphorus, then reacted at 900 ◦C for 72 h.
#Text=The sintered pellet was reground and further annealed at 900 ◦C within argon-filled quartz tubes for several days and finally quenched into iced water.
#Text=A polycrystalline sample of LaPt3P (sample-B) was synthesized using the cubic anvil high-pressure and hightemperature technique.

#Text=Starting powders of LaP and Pt of high purity (99.99%) were weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio, thoroughly ground, and enclosed in a boron nitride container, which was placed inside a pyrophyllite cube with a graphite heater.
#Text=The details of experimental setup can be found in Ref.[3].
#Text=All the work related to the sample preparation and the packing of the high pressure cell-assembly was performed in an argon-filled glove box.
#Text=In a typical run, a pressure of 2 GPa was applied at room temperature.
#Text=The temperature was ramped in 3 h to the maximum value of 1500 ◦C, maintained for 5 h, and then cooled to 1350 ◦C over 5 h and finally reduced to room temperature in 3 h.
#Text=Afterward, the pressure was released, and the sample was removed.
#Text=The sample exhibits a large diamagnetic response with the superconducting transition temperature of 1.1 K.
